A '''compulsory purchase order''' ('''CPO''') is a legal function in the United Kingdom and [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] that allows certain bodies which need to obtain land or property to do so without the consent of the owner. It may be enforced if a proposed development is considered one for public betterment; for example, when building [[motorway]]s where a land owner does not want to sell. Similarly, if [[town council]]s wish to develop a town centre, they may issue compulsory purchase orders. CPOs can also be used to acquire historic buildings in order to preserve them from neglect.
In Ireland, CPOs became quite common in the early 21st century due to the massive road upgrade programme under the [[National Development Plan]]. CPOs are also used for railway projects. If one objects to the issuing of a CPO, one may appeal to the [[High Court (Ireland)|High Court]].<ref>[http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1966/en/act/pub/0021/sec0078.html Housing Act 1966 (ROI)]</ref> Compensation is available to ensure that the person is restored, as far as possible, to the same position that they were in before the land and property were compulsorily purchased, so that the person is left in the same financial position after the CPO as they were in before the process.<ref name="urlCompulsory Purchase">{{cite web |url=http://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/housing/losing_your_home/compulsory_purchase_and_compensation.html |title=Compulsory Purchase |work= |accessdate=}}</ref>
In the United Kingdom, most Orders are made as subordinate legislation under powers given to Local Authorities in existing legislation (e.g. an Order for road works is made under the Highways Act 1980). Whilst the powers are strong, the Authority must demonstrate that the taking of the land is necessary and there is a "compelling case in the public interest". Owners or occupiers can challenge this, and their objection will be heard by an independent Inspector.
Compensation rights usually include the value of the property, costs of acquiring and moving to a new property, and sometimes additional payments. Costs of professional advice regarding compensation are usually reimbursed by the Authority, so that people affected by a compulsory purchase order can seek advice from a [[solicitor]] and a [[surveying|surveyor]] and expect to be reimbursed.

{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2014}} [[File:Madonna à Nice 24.jpg|thumb|Madonna courted a number of controversies while performing throughout [[The MDNA Tour]]]] American singer [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] was embroiled with a number of controversy during [[The MDNA Tour]]. It was her ninth [[concert tour]], promoting her twelfth studio album, ''[[MDNA (album)|MDNA]]'' (2012). The tour has generated many newspaper headlines and news coverage for its use of fake firearms during performances, Madonna's nudity on stage, and her promotion of [[LGBT]] rights, [[freedom of speech]] and political issues.
Madonna was threatened with a lawsuit in [[France]] for using an image of [[French people|French]] [[far-right]] politician [[Marine Le Pen]] with a [[swastika]] on her forehead during a video interlude and also in [[Russia]] for her promotion of the rights of the LGBT community by giving free pink wristbands to people attending her concert.

At the performance in Nice, France at the Stade Charles-Ehrmann, many of Le Pen's supporters had covered up The MDNA Tour announcement posters with Le Pen's campaign posters. It was even speculated that French far right was to attend the show.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.madonnaunderground.nl/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2797%3Afront-national-aanwezig-bij-mdna-in-nice&catid=22%3Aalgemeen&lang=en |title=Front National attending MDNA in Nice? |publisher=Madonnaunderground.nl |date=August 20, 2012 |accessdate=October 20, 2012}}</ref> However, Madonna removed the swastika from the video of "Nobody Knows Me" and replaced it with a question mark. A local party supporter Gael Nofri welcomed the change stating: "As far as I know, Madonna has never changed a video clip. This is proof that our arguments were valid. This is excellent news." Nevertheless, after that performance, Madonna has used the original video clip. Madonna later defended her use of the swastika image, stating she did it to raise awareness of ever growing intolerance towards religious minorities and immigrants (the National Front is [[Opposition to immigration|against immigration]].)
Madonna has been a strong supporter of U.S. President [[Barack Obama]]. She urged fans to vote for Obama and claimed that he is a "Black Muslim" which was largely seen as offensive since Obama is a Christian and has discussed about his faith in the past. Madonna clarified her statements by saying that she merely being ironic and said "Yes, I know Obama is not a Muslim — though I know that plenty of people in this country think he is. And what if he were? The point I was making is that a good man is a good man, no matter who he prays to. I don’t care what religion Obama is — nor should anyone else in America."<ref name="The Huffington Post">{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/09/25/madonna-obama-black-muslim_n_1912400.html | title= Madonna: Obama Is 'A Black Muslim In The White House,' Deserves Votes (VIDEO) [UPDATE] |work=The Huffington Post |date=September 25, 2012 |accessdate=October 24, 2012}}</ref> Madonna's support for President Obama has generally been met with cheers from her audience. However, when Madonna voiced her support for President Obama in the traditionally conservative state of Louisiana during her New Orleans performance, she was booed by the audience. Madonna tried to rectify the situation by saying to her audience, "I don't care who you vote for. Do not take this great privilege for granted." <ref>{{cite web|last=Donnelly|first=Matt|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/gossip/la-et-mg-madonna-obama-boos-concert-new-orleans,0,2837761.story|title=Madonna booed (and cheered) after Obama endorsement in New Orleans|work=Los Angeles Times|date=October 29, 2012|accessdate=October 31, 2012}}</ref>
In her Los Angeles performance, Madonna dedicated her performance to [[Malala Yousafzai]], a 14-year-old Pakistani girl who was shot by the [[Taliban]] for speaking out on her right to have an education. Madonna responded in the concert by saying "This made me cry. The 14-year-old Pakistani girl who was shot on a school bus for writing a blog ... who wrote a blog about how important education was to her. The Taliban stopped her bus and shot her ... Do you understand the sickness and absurdity of this?" Madonna went on to shout, "Support education! Support the people who support women!" Madonna showed the audience a written tattoo on her back with Malala's name on it.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bertram|first=Colin|url=http://www.nbcchicago.com/entertainment/celebrity/Madonna-Offers-Onstage-Support-to-Malala-the-Pakistani-Teen-Shot-by-the-Taliban-173940881.html|title=Madonna Dedicates Song to "Malala," the Pakistani Teen Shot by Taliban Gunmen|publisher=NBC Chicago|date=October 12, 2012|accessdate=October 24, 2012}}</ref>
==Firearms== [[File:Madonna 5, 2012.jpg|thumb|left|Madonna performing "[[Gang Bang (song)|Gang Bang]]" during the show's first segment, This performance received negative backlash due to the involvement of firearms]] In the first section of the show, Madonna performs with fake firearms during the first three songs. She begins with "[[Girl Gone Wild]]" holding a rifle and "breaks" the glass, of a confessional box, she later performs "[[Revolver (song)|Revolver]]" with female dancers dancing with automatic rifles. During the third song, "[[Gang Bang (song)|Gang Bang]]" she performed in a motel setting where she is seen shooting the male dancers who infiltrate her room with blood being splattered on the backdrops.<ref name=perez>{{cite news|last=Hilton|first=Perez|title=Madonna Kicks Off MDNA Tour! Perez Reviews!|url=http://perezhilton.com/2012-05-31-madonna-kicks-off-mdna-tour-perez-reviews|accessdate=June 1, 2012|newspaper=[[Perez Hilton]]|date=June 1, 2012}}</ref> In wake of the [[2012 Aurora shooting]], Madonna was urged to remove the use of firearms from the show. Authorities previously warned the singer about use of guns for the concert in Edinburgh, before the events in [[Colorado]]. However, the order was reinforced after the tragedy occurred. Madonna continued the show in Scotland as planned, with the use of the props. During the concert, she expressed her joy for first concert in the country, saying she could be onstage for three hours. She then joked, "Due to your laws here they might pull the plug on me so if they cut us off suddenly, write to your local [[Member of parliament|MP]]".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/showbiz/2012/07/22/pop-superstar-madonna-ignores-gun-ban-as-she-plays-scots-gig-86908-23911281/ |title=Pop superstar Madonna ignores gun ban as she plays Scots gig |author=Lyons, Beverly|date=July 22, 2012 |work=[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]] |accessdate=July 23, 2012|archiveurl=http://www.freezepage.com/1343079499GTIVONUSYZ?url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/showbiz/2012/07/22/pop-superstar-madonna-ignores-gun-ban-as-she-plays-scots-gig-86908-23911281/ |archivedate=July 23, 2012}}</ref>
Although threatened, Scottish police did not interrupt the show. Activist group, Mothers Against Guns, released a statement stating Madonna "should know better". They further stated the use of the props are in bad taste, even more so after the Colorado shootings. The singer's camp responded saying, "Madonna would rather cancel her show than censor her art. Her entire career, she has fought against people telling her what she can and cannot do. She’s not about to start listening to them now".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/07/23/madonna-guns-concert-photos_n_1694766.html |title=Madonna & Guns: Singer Brandishes Fake Pistols & Machine Guns Despite Warnings, Recent Events (PHOTOS) |author=Makarechi, Kia |date=July 23, 2012 |work=The Huffington Post |accessdate=July 23, 2012|archiveurl=http://www.freezepage.com/1343079799NJKZPFOOWU?url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/07/23/madonna-guns-concert-photos_n_1694766.html|archivedate=July 23, 2012}}</ref>
Following her concert in [[Denver]], [[Colorado]], many fans felt the pop star was being "insensitive" to the community with the use of firearms in the first act. Many concert-goers tweeted the act was "too dark" and "[[Satanism|satanic]]", causing them to leave the show.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kdvr.com/2012/10/19/twitter-madonna-over-2-hours-late-to-denver-show-fakes-shooting-audience/ |title=Madonna over 2 hours late to Denver show, pretends to shoot audience |publisher=KDVR |date=October 19, 2012 |accessdate=November 18, 2012}}</ref> To comment on the story, Liz Rosenberg released the following statement: "It's like taking out the third act of Hamlet. Madonna does not make things pretty and tie them up with a bow".<ref>{{cite news|agency=Associated Press |url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/national/colorado_fans_upset_after_madonna_cGylw7GtnWy1nKesR7h3rM |title=Colorado fans upset after Madonna uses guns during concert |work=New York Post |date=October 19, 2012 |accessdate=November 18, 2012}}</ref> After the controversy in Denver, many fans felt Madonna would not return to the city to perform.
==Nudity== [[File:Madonna 11, 2012.jpg|thumb|upright|Madonna ending the performance of "[[Human Nature (Madonna song)|Human Nature]]" by flashing the crowd at [[KeyArena]] in [[Seattle]].]]While performing her song "[[Human Nature (Madonna song)|Human Nature]]" in her concert in [[Istanbul]] on June 7, 2012, Madonna briefly exposed her right breast to the audience, before covering it up again.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nme.com/news/madonna/64234 |title=Madonna flashes nipple during gig in Istanbul|date=June 10, 2012 |work=[[NME]] |accessdate=July 23, 2012|archiveurl=http://www.freezepage.com/1343080140ZMXDIFQGCI?url=http://www.nme.com/news/madonna/64234 |archivedate=July 23, 2012}}</ref> [[The Sun (United Kingdom)|''The Sun'']] notes, "Her actions may have been offensive to some members of her audience, as Turkey is a traditionally Islamic country, with a largely Muslim population" before noting that "Perhaps fans shouldn't have been surprised - as she did warn them, writing No Fear on her back.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/showbiz/4364974/Madonna-shows-shes-Queen-of-Pop-ping-out-at-MDNA-tour-gig.html |title=Madonna shows shes Queen of Pop-ping out|date=11 June 2012 |work=[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]] |accessdate=23 July 2012|archiveurl=http://www.freezepage.com/1343080267HVYVKHAKRK?url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/showbiz/4364974/Madonna-shows-shes-Queen-of-Pop-ping-out-at-MDNA-tour-gig.html |archivedate=23 July 2012 |location=London}}</ref> Amy Odell from [[BuzzFeed]] said that criticizing the gesture based on her age sends "a very archaic message", adding that "Women who are 53 still have breasts and... sex drives!".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/amyodell/leave-madonnas-53-year-old-breast-alone |title=Leave Madonna's 53-Year-Old Breast Alone|author=Odell, Amy|date=June 2012 |publisher=[[BuzzFeed]] |accessdate=July 23, 2012|archiveurl=http://www.freezepage.com/1343080622SQCIDIJBYO?url=http://www.buzzfeed.com/amyodell/leave-madonnas-53-year-old-breast-alone |archivedate=July 23, 2012}}</ref> Three days later, ''The Sun'' published an article entitled, "Madonna was right to bare her boob at 53." Three readers of the publication recreated the pose, photographed it, and sent it in to the publication to show their support for Madonna "as a positive role model for older women." While some initially claimed Madonna as "clingy" and "desperate", Sarah Angotti, also 53, counters, "I felt nervous when I pulled my bra down but that’s only natural — Madonna probably did too. But then I felt empowered, it was an incredible feeling." She goes on to say about Madonna, "She looks incredible now — better than a woman half her age and better than many of the young girls in the charts now" before commenting on the criticism of Madonna exposing her breast as a parent, "If she is a good mother that’s all that matters." Tina Shaw, also 53, argues Madonna "will not change" despite a double-standard between men and women, opining, "Women always seem to get the most flack when it comes to controversial situations. If it was a 53-year-old famous guy flashing his six-pack on stage, everyone would say, 'Wow, what a lad' but because it’s a woman everyone is saying, 'What an old bag'". Lastly, Sue Scadding, 53 as well, negates the controversy, pointing out that "there are topless women out on the beach every day and nobody bats an eyelid...I mean, it’s only a nipple for goodness sake".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/features/4371665/Madonna-was-right-to-bare-her-boob-at-53.html|title=Madonna was right to bare her boob at 53 |author=Williams, Stewart |date=June 11, 2012 |work=The Sun |accessdate=July 23, 2012|archiveurl=http://www.freezepage.com/1343081055QQXYPSKVBO?url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/features/4371665/Madonna-was-right-to-bare-her-boob-at-53.html|archivedate=July 23, 2012 |location=London}}</ref>
==L'Olympia show== Madonna's second show in Paris at [[L'Olympia]] was met with overwhelmingly negative reviews from fans and critics, with most of the criticism centering on the fact that the concert lasted only 45 minutes, even though the tickets had been sold at the same price as for the others full stage MDNA Tour shows and fans had not been alerted of the abbreviated format of the show. Responding to the criticism, Madonna's publicist declared that her past club shows "were never more than 45 minutes", adding that the concert was "planned as a heartfelt thank you to France which she expressed at the start of the show" and also, the show cost Madonna nearly $1 million to produce and keeping the prices at $100 involved a "tremendous effort".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/entertainment/music/2012/07/28/madonna-booed-after-45-minute-paris-concert |title=Madonna booed after 45-minute Paris concert |work=Sunday Times (Johannesburg) |date=July 28, 2012 |accessdate=November 18, 2012}}</ref> According to TMZ, the riot at Madonna concert in Paris had nothing to do with her brief performance but with around 10 "fans" in the audience who overheard yelling about Marine Le Pen.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.tmz.com/article_head.ftl?id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.tmz.com%2F2012%2F07%2F29%2Fmadonna-france-concert-riot%2F |title=TMZ |publisher=M.tmz.com |accessdate=October 20, 2012}}</ref> However, several French news outlets reported that the backlash against Madonna's performance was started by a considerable number of fans rather than an isolated group of Marine Le Pen supporters.<ref>{{cite web 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/musique/2012/07/27/03006-20120727ARTFIG00530-madonna-sur-twitter-la-reine-est-morte.php|title=Madonna sur Twitter: "La Reine est Morte |work=Elle |date=July 27, 2012 |accessdate=July 27, 2012}}</ref>
==Freedom of speech== [[File:Pussy Riot_- Denis Bochkarev 5.jpg|thumb|left|Madonna called for the release of Russian [[Feminism in Russia|feminist]] [[punk-rock]] band [[Pussy Riot]]]] Madonna's Russian shows in [[Moscow]] and [[Saint Petersburg]] were met with great controversy. Asked her stance on the arrest of feminist punk-rock band [[Pussy Riot]], Madonna responded: "I'm against censorship, and my whole career I've always promoted freedom of expression and [[freedom of speech]] so I think what's happening to them is unfair. And I hope that they don't have to serve 7 years in jail; that would be a tragedy. I think art should be political, that art, historically speaking, always reflects what's going on socially. So for me it's hard to separate being an artist and being political."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newsvideo/9458246/Madonna-calls-for-leniency-in-Pussy-Riot-trial-during-Russian-leg-of-world-tour.html |title=Video: Madonna calls for leniency in Pussy Riot trial during Russian leg of world tour |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=August 7, 2012 |accessdate=October 20, 2012}}</ref> During her [[Moscow]] show, Madonna gave a speech in support of the band, saying "...My dream, and my prayer, is that everyone in the world has the right to express their opinions and still be treated as human beings. I know there are many sides to every story, and I mean no disrespect to the Church, or the government, but I think that these three girls -- Nadezhda, Yekaterina, and Maria -- have done something courageous. I think that they have paid the price for this act. And I pray for their freedom."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/video/2012/aug/08/madonna-pussy-riot-moscow-video |title=Madonna shows support for Pussy Riot at Moscow concert – video |work=The Guardian |date=August 8, 2012 |accessdate=October 20, 2012}}</ref> Madonna later appeared on stage with a [[temporary tattoo]] that said "Pussy Riot" on her back in place of the usual "No Fear" slogan, and performed "[[Like a Virgin (song)|Like a Virgin]]" donning a balaclava covering her face, the band's trademark.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2012/08/08/madonna-supports-pussy-riot_n_1755804.html |title=Madonna Dons Pussy Riot's Trademark Balaclava To Show Support In Moscow, Russia (PICTURES) |work=The Huffington Post |date=August 8, 2012 |accessdate=October 20, 2012}}</ref> It was considered an artistic statement against the oppression of the band's [[freedom of speech]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Associated |first=The |url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/entertainment/madonna-dons-balaclava-in-moscow-to-show-support-for-anti-putin-punk-band-1.907178 |title=Madonna dons balaclava in Moscow to show support for jailed members of punk band Pussy Riot |publisher=Yahoo!|date=August 8, 2012 |accessdate=October 20, 2012}}</ref>
The response was largely positive. Many media outlets lauded Madonna's efforts, and other artists joined her in support of the band, among them [[Yoko Ono]], [[Paul McCartney]] and [[Peter Gabriel]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bbc-worldnews.net/2012/08/peter-gabriel-joins-madonna-paul-mccartney-in-backing-pussy-riot/ |publisher=BBC News|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120819214737/http://bbc-worldnews.net/2012/08/peter-gabriel-joins-madonna-paul-mccartney-in-backing-pussy-riot/|title=Peter Gabriel joins Madonna, Paul McCartney in backing Pussy Riot|date=August 1, 2012|accessdate=December 22, 2013|archivedate=August 19, 2012 }}</ref> [[Pussy Riot]] themselves tweeted: "DEAR MADONNA! We love you and you just might be changing Russia's history right now. Thank you and a thousand prayers in return!"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/madonna/65390 |title=Madonna prays for Pussy Riot on stage in Moscow |work=NME |date=August 8, 2012 |accessdate=October 20, 2012}}</ref> Deputy Prime Minister [[Dmitry Rogozin]], however, wrote an expletive-ridden [[Twitter]] post lambasting Madonna for backing the band: "With age, every ex-slut tends to lecture everybody on morality. Especially during world tours and concerts."<ref>{{cite web|first=Miriam |last=Elder |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2012/aug/09/pussy-riot-madonna-called-moralising-slut |title=Pussy Riot case: Madonna labelled moralising 'slut' |work=The Guardian |date=August 9, 2012 |accessdate=October 20, 2012}}</ref> Madonna's second Russian date in [[Saint Petersburg]] was consequently met with terrorist threats, prompting the U.S. Embassy to issue a warning to those in attendance.<ref name="cnn.com">{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/08/07/showbiz/russia-madonna/index.html |title=Violence threatened at Madonna concerts in Russia, embassy warns |publisher=CNN |date=August 8, 2012 |accessdate=October 20, 2012}}</ref> Madonna's spokesperson Liz Rosenberg responded that the concert would go on as scheduled and that Russian authorities would step up security for the date.<ref name="cnn.com"/>
Following threats of arrest by Russian officials if she spoke in support of [[gay rights]] and opposed the recent anti-gay law which prohibits "public actions aimed at propaganda of sodomy, lesbianism, bisexuality, and transgenderism among minors", Madonna responded, on March 21, in a letter on her website:
{{Quote|I'm a freedom fighter. My show. My songs. My work. My art, is all about freedom of expression. Freedom to choose to speak to act. Always with humanity and compassion. I will come to St. Petersburg to speak up for the gay community, to support the gay community and to give strength and inspiration to anyone who is or feels oppressed. I don't run away from adversity. I will speak during my show about this ridiculous atrocity.<ref name="madonna.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.madonna.com/news/title/madonna-answers-st-petersburgs-controversy |title=> News > Madonna Answers St Petersburg's Controversy |publisher=Madonna.com |accessdate=October 20, 2012}}</ref><ref name="madonna.com"/><ref name="tv.ibtimes.com">{{cite web|url=http://tv.ibtimes.com/anti-gay-law-to-take-effect-in-russia-s-second-city-st-petersburg/4200.html |title=Anti-Gay Law to Take Effect in Russia's Second City St. Petersburg |work=International Business Times |date=March 16, 2012 |accessdate=October 20, 2012}}</ref><ref name="tv.ibtimes.com"/> }}
On August 18, [[Pussy Riot]] members were found guilty and sentenced to two years in prison.<ref>{{cite web|last=Marsh |first=Julia |url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/international/fury_over_pussy_whippin_1vxUnTGTJYxhmK2syCfX0M |title=Russian punk trio Pussy Riot gets two years’ prison, igniting protests worldwide |work=New York Post |date=August 18, 2012 |accessdate=October 20, 2012}}</ref> In response, Madonna wrote on her website in further support of the band: "I protest the conviction and sentencing of Pussy Riot to a penal colony for two years for a 40 second performance extolling their political opinions. Even if one disagrees with the location or how they chose to express themselves, the sentence is too harsh and in fact is inhumane. I call on all those who love freedom to condemn this unjust punishment. I urge artists around the world to speak up in protest against this travesty. They've spent enough time in jail. I call on ALL of Russia to let Pussy Riot go free."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://madonna.com/news/title/temp |title=> News > From Madonna Aug 18th, 2012 |publisher=Madonna.com |accessdate=November 18, 2012}}</ref> Madonna also continued to back and defend Pussy Riot and preach for equality and freedom.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/5/33/50950/Arts--Culture/Music/Madonna-drops-swastika-from-France-concert,-backs-.aspx|title=Madonna drops swastika from France concert, backs Pussy Riot|publisher=Ahram Online|date=August 22, 2012|accessdate=August 22, 2012}}</ref>
Following her tour in Europe, Madonna returned to the United States to perform. Madonna urged her U.S. fans to appreciate their freedom of speech and claimed, "I've seen some scary things. I've seen people being locked up and put in jail for speaking their minds, for being gay, for not practicing the right religion, for not dressing the proper way. Yeah, it's scary. But what it made me realize is how lucky I am to be living here in America. It doesn't mean that this is the perfect country. We have a long way to go." <ref name="The Huffington Post"/>
==LGBT rights== [[File:MDNAMasterpiece.jpg|thumb|Madonna's performance of "[[Masterpiece (Madonna song)|Masterpiece]]" was normally preceded by a speech.]]Before the show, Madonna released pink wristbands to audience members in support of the [[LGBT community]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://madonna.com/news/title/support-the-gay-lesbian-community-at-madonnas-st-petersburg-show |title=> News > Support the LGBT Community At Madonna's St. Petersburg Show |publisher=Madonna.com |accessdate=October 20, 2012}}</ref> In addition, hundreds brought rainbow flags to the show and waved them throughout. Madonna stopped in the middle of the show to speak on the issues at hand: "...I feel that people are becoming more and more afraid of people who are different. People are becoming more and more intolerant, but we can make a difference...we don't have to do it with violence, but love." She continued, noting [[Martin Luther King, Jr.]] as a fighter for the equal rights of African Americans, and stating, "I am here to say that the gay community and gay people here, and all around the world, have the same rights, to be treated with dignity, respect, tolerance, compassion, and love." She then asked the audience to raise their wristbands with her to show their "love and support of the gay community." She concluded, "for people quoting the [[Bible]], and using [[God]] as a defense mechanism: [[Jesus]], [[Muhammad]], [[Buddha]], and [[Moses]] preached this—it's in every Holy book—'love thy neighbor as thyself'. You can not use religion, or God's name, to treat other people badly. So let's go out into the world, and spread this message of love, and live our lives without fear. Amen."<ref>{{cite web|last=Edward |first=Brett |url=http://www.advocate.com/arts-entertainment/music/2012/08/10/madonna-transforms-st-petersburg-concert-unofficial-gay-pride |title=Madonna Transforms St Petersburg Concert into Unofficial Gay Pride Rally |work=The Advocate |date=August 10, 2012 |accessdate=October 20, 2012}}</ref>
Though her speech was met with much praise from the media, on August 17, it was announced that anti-gay Russian campaigners would sue Madonna for $10.4 million, arguing that she was promoting "homosexual propaganda" which was against the law, and allegedly "insulted their feelings when she spoke out for gay rights" at the concert.<ref name="guardian">{{cite news|agency=Reuters |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2012/aug/17/madonna-sued-gay-rights-russia?newsfeed=true |title=Madonna sued over gay rights stance by Russian campaigners |work=The Guardian |date=August 17, 2012 |accessdate=October 20, 2012}}</ref> According to one of the 10 activists who filed the lawsuit, "She (Madonna) had been warned with words that she should behave in line with the law and she ignored it. So we will speak in the language of money...maybe someone does not see the link but after Madonna's concert maybe some boy becomes gay, some girl becomes lesbian, fewer children are born as a result and this big country cannot defend its borders—for me it causes moral suffering."<ref>{{cite news|first=Liza |last=Dobkina |agency=Reuters |url=http://www.torontosun.com/2012/08/17/anti-gay-activists-sue-madonna-over-hurt-feelings |title=Anti-gay activists sue Madonna over hurt feelings |work=Toronto Sun |date=August 17, 2012 |accessdate=October 20, 2012}}</ref> On November 12 the claims were fully rejected.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rapsinews.com/judicial_news/20121122/265459436.html|title=Madonna gay propaganda trial - live updates|work=RAPSI - Russian Legal Information Agency|accessdate=2017-11-24|date=2012-11-12}}</ref>

{{no footnotes|date=March 2012}} {{notability|date=March 2012}} '''"Criminalization of politics"''' is a political [[buzzword]] in the [[United States]] used in the media, by commentators, bloggers as well as by defenders of high-ranking government officials who have been indicted or have faced criminal or ethical investigations.
Most recently, the term has been applied to proceedings against [[President of the United States|President]] [[George W. Bush]]'s advisers and the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] leadership in [[United States Congress|Congress]], including [[Tom DeLay]], [[Bill Frist]], and [[Karl Rove]] (see [[Plame affair]]). The position of their defenders, who include [[Robert Novak]], [[William Kristol]] and [[Rush Limbaugh]], is that the accusations against these officials lack substance and [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] partisans seek to weaken them for political reasons, perhaps to the point of retaking Congress in 2006.
The position of many Democrats is that the cause of the plethora of investigations is the "[[2006 Republican party scandals|culture of corruption]]" established by the Republicans in power, and that anyone who has broken laws or rules must face the consequences. The opponents also point out that some of the politicians denouncing the current pursuit of alleged Republican misconduct have in the past called for vigorous pursuit of alleged Democratic misconduct.
The phrase was previously used by supporters of President [[Bill Clinton]] in reference to legal action against members of his administration, including [[Henry Cisneros]]. During the [[Watergate scandal]], supporters of [[Richard Nixon]] claimed that he was guilty of nothing more than "hard-ball politics."

The '''delegate model of representation''' is a model of a [[representative democracy]]. In this model, [[Electoral district|constituents]] elect their representatives as [[delegates]] for their [[constituency]]. These delegates act only as a mouthpiece for the wishes of their constituency/ state, and have no [[Wiktionary:autonomy|autonomy]] from the constituency only the autonomy to vote for the actual representatives of the state. This model does not provide representatives the luxury of acting in their own conscience. Essentially, the representative acts as the voice of those who are (literally) not present.
This model was contested by [[Edmund Burke]] (1729-1797), an Irish philosopher, who also created the [[trustee model of representation]].
==Further reading== *Burke, Edmund. '''1774''' (1906). ''Speech to the electors of Bristol'' in The Works of the Right Honorable Edmund Burke. Vol. II. New York: Oxford University Press.

{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox organization |name = Free State Project |image = Free State Project Logo.svg |caption = Logo of the Free State Project |headquarters = 373 South Willow St #161, [[Manchester, New Hampshire|Manchester]], {{nowrap|[[New Hampshire]]}}, United States |leader_title = Executive Director |leader_name = Rachel Goldsmith |formation = September 1, 2001 |motto = "Liberty in Our Lifetime" |website = {{url|fsp.org}} |remarks = 20,000 people have pledged (February 3, 2016)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fsp.org/free-state-project-triggers-the-move-libertarians-new-hampshire/|title=Free State Project Triggers the Move|work=fsp.org|accessdate=June 7, 2018}}</ref> }} The '''Free State Project''' ('''FSP''') is a proposed [[political migration]] founded in 2001 to recruit at least 20,000 [[Libertarianism in the United States|libertarians]] to move to a single low-population state ([[New Hampshire]], selected in 2003) in order to make the state a stronghold for libertarian ideas.<ref>{{cite news|title=Libertarians Pursue New Political Goal: State of Their Own|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/10/27/us/libertarians-pursue-new-political-goal-state-of-their-own.html?pagewanted=all|first=Pam|last=Belluck|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=October 27, 2003|accessdate=May 26, 2011}}</ref> The project seeks to overcome the historical ineffectiveness of [[limited government]] activism which they believe was caused by the small number and diffuse population of libertarian activists across the 50 United States and around the world.
Participants sign a statement of intent declaring that they intend to move to New Hampshire within five years of the drive reaching 20,000 participants. This statement of intent is intended to function as a form of [[assurance contract]]. {{As of|2016|2|3|df=US}}, 20,000 people have signed this statement of intent<ref name=membership>{{cite web|title=Free State Project Triggers the Move|url=https://www.fsp.org/free-state-project-triggers-the-move-libertarians-new-hampshire/|publisher=Free State Project|accessdate=June 7, 2018}}</ref>—completing the original goal—and 1,909 people are listed as "early movers" to New Hampshire on the FSP website, saying they had made their move prior to the 20,000-participant trigger.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/id/2296999/|title=Free State Project: What happens if 20,000 libertarians move to New Hampshire?|work=Slate Magazine|accessdate=April 23, 2015}}</ref> Approximately a dozen Free Staters were elected to the New Hampshire House of Representatives in the 2012 election<ref>{{cite web|first=Jake|last=Berry|url=http://www.nashuatelegraph.com/news/994856-469/movement-starts-slowly-but-future-encouraging.html|title=Free State project says future is encouraging|work=Nashua Telegraph|date=February 24, 2013|accessdate=February 24, 2013}}</ref> and about 18 in the 2014 election.
The FSP is a social movement generally based upon [[decentralized decision making]]. The group hosts various events, but most of FSP's activities depend upon volunteers, and no formal plan dictates to participants or movers what their actions should be in New Hampshire.
==Intent== The FSP mission statement, adopted in 2005, states: {{Cquote|The Free State Project is an agreement among 20,000 pro-liberty activists to move to New Hampshire, where they will exert the fullest practical effort toward the creation of a society in which the maximum role of government is the protection of life, liberty, and property. The success of the Project would likely entail reductions in taxation and regulation, reforms at all levels of government to expand individual rights and free markets, and a restoration of constitutional federalism, demonstrating the benefits of liberty to the rest of the nation and the world.<ref>[http://www.freestateproject.org/about/mission.php Mission Statement] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130118215151/http://freestateproject.org/about/mission.php |date=January 18, 2013 }} from the Free State Project website</ref>}}
"Life, liberty, and property" are rights that were enumerated in the October 1774 [[Declaration and Resolves of the First Continental Congress]]<ref>{{cite web| title= Declaration and Resolves of the First Continental Congress | url= http://avalon.law.yale.edu/18th_century/resolves.asp | date= October 14, 1774 | work= [[Avalon Project]] | publisher= [[Yale Law School]] | accessdate=November 11, 2010| quote=That the inhabitants of the English colonies in North-America, by the immutable laws of nature, the principles of the English constitution, and the several charters or compacts, have the following RIGHTS: Resolved, N.C.D. 1. That they are entitled to life, liberty and property: and they have never ceded to any foreign power whatever, a right to dispose of either without their consent.}}</ref> and in [[Constitution of New Hampshire#Article 12–a. Eminent domain|Article 12]] of the [[Constitution of New Hampshire|New Hampshire Constitution]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nh.gov/constitution/billofrights.html|title=NH.gov – The Official Web Site of New Hampshire State Government – State Constitution, Bill of Rights|work=nh.gov|accessdate=April 23, 2015}}</ref>
To become a participant of the Free State Project, a person is asked to agree to the Statement of Intent (SOI): {{Cquote|I hereby state my solemn intent to move to the State of New Hampshire within 5 years after 20,000 Participants have signed up. Once there, I will exert the fullest practical effort toward the creation of a society in which the maximum role of civil government is the protection of individuals' life, liberty, and property.}}
==Eligibility== The FSP is open to people with a minimum age of 18 and United States citizenship is not required; people who promote violence, racial hatred, or bigotry are not welcome in the FSP.<ref>[https://www.fsp.org/disclaimer-policies/ FSP Disclaimer and Policies]</ref>
==History==
===Origins=== The Free State Project was founded in 2001 by [[Jason Sorens]], then a Ph.D. student at [[Yale University]].<ref>{{cite web| author=Larry Clow |url=http://www.wirenh.com/Features/Cover_Story/the_Free_State_turns_two_20051005785.html |title=The Free State turns two |publisher=The Wire |date=October 5, 2005 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121017050136/http://www.wirenh.com/Features/Cover_Story/the_Free_State_turns_two_20051005785.html |archivedate=October 17, 2012 }}</ref> Sorens published an article in ''[[The Libertarian Enterprise]]'' highlighting the failure of libertarians to elect any candidate to federal office and outlining his ideas for a [[secession]]ist movement, calling people to respond to him with interest.<ref name="tlesoren">{{cite journal| last=Sorens | first= Jason | url= http://www.ncc-1776.org/tle2001/libe131-20010723-03.html | title=Announcement: The Free State Project | journal=The Libertarian Enterprise | volume=131 | date=July 23, 2001}}</ref> Sorens soon published a follow-up article <ref name="sorensfollowup">{{cite journal| last=Sorens | first= Jason | url= http://www.ncc-1776.org/tle2001/libe133-20010806-02.html | title=Update: Free State Project | journal=The Libertarian Enterprise | volume=132| date=August 6, 2001}}</ref> backing away from secession, "and it never played a role in the FSP’s philosophy from then on.<ref name="fsphistory">{{cite web|title=The Early Years of the Free State Project|url=https://www.fsp.org/history/|publisher=Free State Project|accessdate=7 June 2018}}</ref>" Sorens has stated that the movement continues an American tradition of [[political migration]], which includes groups such as [[Mormon]] settlers in [[Utah]], [[Amish]] religious communities<ref name="guardian">{{cite web| author=Joanna Walters | url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2003/oct/01/usa.joannawalters | title=Free staters pick New Hampshire to liberate for sex, guns and drugs | work= [[The Guardian]] | date=October 1, 2003}}</ref> and the "Jamestown Seventy",<ref>{{cite journal| url=http://digitalcommons.law.yale.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1006&context=yrlsa |first1=James F. |last1=Blumstein |first2=James |last2=Phelan |title=Jamestown Seventy |date=1971 |journal=[[Yale Review of Law and Social Action]] |volume=1 |issue=1}}</ref> an earlier effort to influence the politics of a particular state through deliberate migration.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=The Libertarian Enterprise |volume=132 |date=August 6, 2001 |title=Update: Free State Project |last=Sorens |first=Jason |url=http://www.ncc-1776.org/tle2001/libe133-20010806-02.html}}</ref>
[[File:FSP Gadsden Flag.gif|thumb|left|The flag of the Free State Project, a modified [[Gadsden flag]]]] The organization began without a specific state in mind. A systematic review started by narrowing potential states to those with a population of less than 1.5 million and those where the combined spending in 2000 by the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] and [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] parties was less than $5.2 million, the total national spending by the [[Libertarian Party (United States)|Libertarian Party]] in that year. [[Hawaii]] and [[Rhode Island]] were eliminated from this list because of their propensity for centralized government.<ref>Joseph Spear, [http://www.libarts.ucok.edu/opsa/OPSR/Journal%20Vol5-Number1/4-Student%20Contri%20butions.pdf "An Experiment in Civic Engagement: The Free State Project"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090325044314/http://www.libarts.ucok.edu/opsa/OPSR/Journal%20Vol5-Number1/4-Student%20Contri%20butions.pdf |date=March 25, 2009 }}, ''Oklahoma Policy Studies Review'', Vol. 5, No. 1.</ref>
===State selection=== In September 2003, the state vote was held and participants voted using the [[Condorcet method]] to choose the state.<ref name="upandcoming">Pete Camp, [http://old.freestateproject.org/archives/state_vote/FSP-ECL-CertifyWhitePaper.htm "Free State Project Picks New Hampshire"], ''Up & Coming Magazine'', October 8, 2003.</ref> New Hampshire was the winner, with Wyoming coming in second by a 57% to 43% margin.<ref name="upandcoming" /> Alaska, Delaware, Idaho, Maine, Montana, North Dakota, South Dakota and Vermont were also on the list.<ref name="guardian"/>
New Hampshire was chosen because the perceived individualist culture of the state was thought to resonate well with libertarian ideals.<ref name="boston"/> However, the Free State Project has drawn criticism from some New Hampshire residents concerned about population pressure and opposition to increased taxation. On the other hand, some Republicans have responded more favorably to the project because they also favor a small government.<ref>Meredith Goldstein, [http://www.boston.com/news/local/articles/2003/10/09/free_state_project_pushes_limits_of_liberty_in_nh/ "Free State Project pushes limits of liberty in N.H."], ''Boston Globe'', October 19, 2003.</ref>
===Recent events=== In December 2012, state representative [[Cynthia Chase]] (D-Keene) said "Free Staters are the single biggest threat the state is facing today. There is, legally, nothing we can do to prevent them from moving here to take over the state, which is their openly stated goal. In this country you can move anywhere you choose and they have that same right. What we can do is to make the environment here so unwelcoming that some will choose not to come, and some may actually leave. One way is to pass measures that will restrict the “freedoms” that they think they will find here".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://reason.com/blog/2012/12/27/new-hampshire-democrat-free-staters-are|title=New Hampshire Democrat: 'Free Staters are the single biggest threat the state is facing today'|work=Reason.com|accessdate=April 23, 2015}}</ref>
In 2012, the Concord Police Department applied for $258,000 in federal government funding to buy a [[Lenco BearCat]] armored vehicle for protection against terrorist attacks, riots, or shooting incidents. The application said: "Groups such as the Sovereign Citizens, Free Staters and Occupy New Hampshire are active and present daily challenges". The grant from the [[United States Department of Homeland Security]] was successful and the Concord City Council unanimously approved of the grant after having revised the application to remove references to those political movements.<ref>{{cite news|last=Wickham|first=Shawne K.|title=Civil Liberties Union questions increasing use of costly military-style equipment by NH law enforcement|url=http://www.unionleader.com/article/20130728/NEWS07/130729284|newspaper=Union Leader|date=July 27, 2013|location=Manchester, New Hampshire}}</ref>
In September 2014, Republican Party Senate nominee [[Scott Brown (politician)|Scott Brown]], a former [[United States Senate|United States Senator]] from [[Massachusetts]], said his election campaign needed "Freestaters" to support him in his one-minute closing statement at the Granite State Debate.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YMtg48fQocE|title=Granite State Debate, U.S. Senate: Candidates deliver closing statements|date=September 4, 2014 |accessdate=September 10, 2014}}</ref>
===Move triggered=== On February 3, 2016, the Free State Project announced via social media that 20,000 people had signed the Statement of Intent.<ref>{{cite web|title=Free State Project|publisher=[[Twitter]]|date=February 2, 2016|url=https://twitter.com/FreeStateNH/status/694763068010713088?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Etweet}}</ref> In a press conference later that day, then FSP president [[Carla Gericke]] officially announced that the move had been triggered and that signers were expected to follow up on their pledge.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://freestateproject.org/blogs/free-state-project-officially-announces-20000-signers-100-reached|website=Freestateproject.org|date=2016|title=Official press conference announcing success in reaching 20,000 members}}</ref> The project organization will change focus from recruiting signers to encouraging them to move to New Hampshire, stating "we want 20,000 movers".
==Political positions== The Free State Project aligns itself with no political party, takes no official political positions, supports no candidates in elections and neither supports nor opposes any particular legislation.<ref>[http://freestateproject.org/intro Introduction to the Free State Project] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130601025020/http://freestateproject.org/intro |date=June 1, 2013 }}</ref>
The Free State Project receives its funding from individual donors interested in moving as part of the FSP or attending one of the annual events.<ref>[http://freestateproject.org/files/FSPFY2008Actuals.pdf Total income donations, FSPFY2008Actuals.pdf] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120816065430/http://freestateproject.org/files/FSPFY2008Actuals.pdf |date=August 16, 2012 }}</ref><ref>[http://freestateproject.org/files/FSPFY2009-090331.pdf Total income donations FSPFY2009Actuals.pdf] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120816065452/http://freestateproject.org/files/FSPFY2009-090331.pdf |date=August 16, 2012 }}</ref> Donations are tax deductible as the FSP is a tax-exempt nonprofit educational organization, falling under category 501(c)(3). This affects all donations since July 20, 2009.<ref>[https://madmimi.com/s/bc2215 FSP Newsletter], July 2014, From the President's Desk</ref>
Several early movers have been elected to the New Hampshire legislature. In 2006, one of its participants, [[Joel Winters]], was elected to the [[New Hampshire General Court|state legislature]], running as a [[New Hampshire Democratic Party|Democrat]].<ref name="boston">{{cite web| subscription=yes|author= Sarah Schweitzer | title=Free State Project cheers on one of its own in Winters | url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/articles/2006/11/26/free_state_project_cheers_one_of_its_own_in_winters/ | publisher=The Boston Globe | date=November 16, 2006}}</ref> He was re-elected in 2008, but defeated in 2010.<ref>[http://www.sos.nh.gov/electwinwin.html List of Nov. 2010 winners] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120205082004/http://www.sos.nh.gov/electwinwin.html |date=February 5, 2012 }}</ref> In 2010, 12 Republican Free Staters were elected to the New Hampshire House of Representatives.<ref name="nationaljournal">{{cite web | url=http://www.nationaljournal.com/politics/for-some-ron-paul-backers-a-new-motto-go-east-young-man-and-woman--20110510 | title=For Some Ron Paul Backers, a New Motto: Go East, Young Man (and Woman) | publisher=NationalJournal.com | date=May 10, 2011 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ArZQc604?url=http://www.nationaljournal.com/politics/for-some-ron-paul-backers-a-new-motto-go-east-young-man-and-woman--20110510 | archivedate=September 22, 2012 | df= }}</ref>
On December 5, 2012, Free Stater and self-described anarchist [[Tim O'Flaherty]] was elected to the state House of Representatives under the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] ticket, representing Manchester Ward 5.<ref name=Hayward>{{cite web| url=http://www.unionleader.com/article/20121115/LOCALVOICES08/121119494 |date=November 14, 2012 |title=Anarchy in Ward 5? Well, not exactly |first=Mark |last=Hayward |publisher=Manchester Union Leader}}</ref> He was defeated for re-election in 2014.
In 2012, elected participants wrote and passed House Bill 418 which requires state agencies to consider [[Open-source software|open source]] software and data formats when making acquisitions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://yro.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=2654797&cid=38931563|title=New Hampshire Passes 'Open Source Bill' - Slashdot|work=slashdot.org|accessdate=April 23, 2015}}</ref> However, it died in the Senate.<ref>[https://legiscan.com/NH/bill/HB418/2011 New Hampshire House Bill 418]</ref>
==Annual events== The Free State Project is the official organizer of two annual events in New Hampshire: * The [[New Hampshire Liberty Forum]] is a convention-style event with a wide variety of speakers, dinners and events. * The Porcupine Freedom Festival (PorcFest)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://porcfest.com|title=PorcFest|work=PorcFest|accessdate=April 23, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fsp.org/tag/porcupine-freedom-festival/|title=Porcupine Freedom Festival Blog Entries|work=fsp.org|accessdate=June 12, 2018}}</ref> is a weeklong summer festival that takes place at a campground and it is "like [[Woodstock]] for rational people", says [[Roderick Long]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://aaeblog.com/2011/06/22/way-long-gone-part-2/|title=Way Long Gone, Part 2|work=aaeblog.com|accessdate=April 23, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://aaeblog.com/2011/07/09/way-long-gone-part-3/|title=Way Long Gone, Part 3|work=aaeblog.com|accessdate=April 23, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Murphy|first1=Robert P.|title=PorcFest 2011|url=https://mises.org/daily/5430/PorcFest-2011|publisher=[[Ludwig von Mises Institute]]|accessdate=July 7, 2014}}</ref>
==New Hampshire House of Representatives== In 2006, Democrat Joel Winters became the first known free stater to become elected to the 400-member [[New Hampshire House of Representatives]].<ref name="boston"/> Every two years, the entire House is up for election. In 2010, 12 Free Staters were elected.<ref name="nationaljournal"/> In 2012, 11 more were elected.<ref name="Hayward"/> In 2014, at least 18 were elected.<ref>[http://ballotpedia.org/New_Hampshire_House_of_Representatives_elections,_2014 New Hampshire House of Representatives elections, 2014], Ballotpedia</ref><ref>[http://freestateprojectwatch.org/free-state-project-watch-candidate-list-2014/ Free State Project Watch: Candidate List 2014], Free State Project Watch</ref> In 2016, at least 15 were elected (out of 32).<ref>{{cite web|title=NH Libertarians Officially Recognized as Party For First time in 20 Years + “Free Staters” Win 15+ State Rep Races|url=http://freekeene.com/2016/11/09/nh-libertarians-officially-recognized-as-party-for-first-time-in-20-years-free-staters-win-15-state-rep-races/|website=Free Keene|accessdate=March 7, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Free State Project Watch: Candidate List 2016|url=https://freestateprojectwatch.org/free-state-project-watch-candidate-list-2016/|website=Free State Project Watch|accessdate=March 7, 2017}}</ref>
===Currently elected Free Staters=== * Belknap District 2, [[Glen C. Aldrich]], Republican * Belknap District 6, [[Mike Sylvia]], Republican * Carroll District 5, [[Ed Comeau (politician)|Ed Comeau]], Republican * Grafton District 9, [[Robert Hull (politician)|Robert Hull]], Republican * Hillsborough District 11, [[Elizabeth Edwards (politician)|Elizabeth Edwards]], Democrat * Hillsborough District 12, [[Amanda Bouldin]], Democrat * Hillsborough District 40, [[Keith Ammon]], Republican * Hillsborough District 7, [[Keith Murphy]], Republican * Merrimack District 20, [[Brian Seaworth]], Republican * Merrimack District 21, [[Dan McGuire]], Republican * Merrimack District 29, [[Carol McGuire]], Republican * Rockingham District 4, Jason Osborne, Republican * Strafford District 24, [[Laura Jones (politician)|Laura Jones]], Republican
===Formerly elected Free Staters=== ; 2010: * [[Jenn Coffey]] (R-): represented the district of Merrimack-6 until she lost re-election in 2012<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.granitestateprogress.org/legislator/coffey|title=Coffey – Granite State Progress|work=granitestateprogress.org|accessdate=April 23, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150604055802/http://www.granitestateprogress.org/legislator/coffey|archivedate=June 4, 2015|df=}}</ref>
; 2012: * [[Cal Pratt]] (R-Goffstown): the district of Hillsborough-6 * Tim O'Flaherty (D-Manchester): the district of Hillsborough-12 * [[Emily Sandblade]] (R-Manchester): the district of Hillsborough-18 * Rockingham District 14 [[Shem Kellogg]] Republican * Joel Winters (D-Manchester): the district of Hillsborough-18 * [[Michael Garcia (New Hampshire politician)|Michael Garcia]] (D-Nashua): the district of Hillsborough-34 * [[Mark Warden]] (R-Goffstown): the district of Hillsborough-39
==Responses== On February 17, 2006, economist [[Walter Block]] publicly expressed his support for the FSP and is quoted as saying: {{Cquote|You people are doing the Lord's work. The FSP is one of the freshest practical ideas for promoting liberty that has come out of the libertarian movement in the past few decades. May you succeed beyond your wildest dreams, and thus demonstrate in yet another empirical way the benefits and blessings of liberty.<ref>[http://freestateproject.org/about/endorsements#block Walter Block's endorsement of the Free State Project]. ''FreeStateProject.org.'' 17 February 2006.</ref>}}
[[Jeffrey Tucker]] reflected about his experiences at the [[New Hampshire Liberty Forum]] in [[Nashua, New Hampshire|Nashua]], saying in part: "If you are willing to look past mainstream media coverage of American politics, you can actually find exciting and interesting activities taking place that rise above lobbying, voting, graft and corruption".<ref>{{cite web|title=Political Migration in Our Time |url=http://freestateproject.org/content/political-migration-our-time |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130310194902/http://freestateproject.org/content/political-migration-our-time |archivedate=March 10, 2013 }}</ref>
The project has been endorsed by [[Ron Paul]]<ref>{{cite web |title=Ron Paul Supports the Free State Project |url=http://freestateproject.org/intro/ron_paul |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130519122424/http://freestateproject.org/intro/ron_paul |archivedate=May 19, 2013 |df= }}</ref> and [[Gary Johnson]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Gary Johnson Endorses the FSP|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TzLw12pbIU4}}</ref>
In 2010, [[Lew Rockwell]] from the [[Mises Institute]] endorsed the project and referred to the city of [[Keene, New Hampshire]] as "The northern capital of libertarianism".<ref>{{cite web|title=Lew Rockwell Applauds the Free State Project|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Md6zzipKNVE}}</ref>
In 2011, [[Peter Schiff]] said he had considered moving at one point.<ref>{{cite web|title=Peter Schiff (Euro Pacific Capital Inc.) |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v6BmdaZK3Zg}}</ref>
Critics argue that the Free State Project is "radical",<ref>{{cite web| url=http://thinkprogress.org/climate/2011/04/13/174973/new-hampshire-radical-right/?mobile=nc| title=The Radical-Right Free State Project Has Chosen New Hampshire For A Revolution| publisher=Thinkprogress.org| date=April 13, 2011| accessdate=September 14, 2012}}</ref> a "fantasy",<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.rationalreview.com/rationalreviewold/archive/stevetrinward/stevetrinward011203.html| title=The Free State Project: good idea or libertopian fantasy?| author=Steve Trinward| publisher=Rational Review| accessdate=September 14, 2012}}</ref> or that they "go too far" in seeking to restrict government.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://thecontributor.com/lte-free-staters-go-too-far| title=LTE: Free Staters go too far| publisher=Concord Monitor| date=June 28, 2012| accessdate=June 29, 2016}}</ref>
The Free State Project was the centerpiece of the 2011 documentary film ''Libertopia''<ref>{{cite web |url =http://www.filmbuff.com/movies/libertopia/ |title =Libertopia |publisher =FilmBuff |accessdate=October 29, 2012 }}</ref> as well as the 2014 crowdfunded documentary ''101 Reasons: Liberty Lives in New Hampshire''.<ref>{{cite web |url =http://www.shirelibertynews.com/new-documentary-to-highlight-101-reasons-to-move-to-new-hampshire/ |title =101 Reasons: Liberty Lives in New Hampshire |accessdate=December 16, 2014 }}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} "'''Freedom Flotilla II – Stay Human'''"<ref>{{cite news |last=Bannoura |first=Saed |date=27 June 2011 |url=http://www.aljazeerah.info/News/2011/June/27%20n/German%20activists%20hold%20'solidarity%20flotilla'%20in%20Berlin%20canals.htm |title=German activists hold 'solidarity flotilla' in Berlin canals |work=Al-Jazeerah: Cross-Cultural Understanding |agency=IMEMC News |accessdate=16 August 2011}}</ref> was a [[flotilla]] that planned to break the [[Blockade of the Gaza Strip (2007-present)|maritime blockade]] of the [[Gaza Strip]] by Israel by sailing to Gaza on 5 July 2011. Ultimately, the sailing did not take place.<ref>{{cite news |author=JTA |date=1 July 2011 |title=Flotilla delayed until next week |url=http://www.jewishjournal.com/israel/article/flotilla_delayed_until_next_week_20110701/ |work=Jewish Journal |accessdate=2 July 2011}}</ref>
The flotilla was organized by a coalition of 22 NGOs. Its name refers to the May 2010 [[Gaza Flotilla Raid|Gaza Freedom Flotilla]]. Their stated goal was to end the blockade of Gaza "completely and permanently".<ref>{{cite press release |date=18 June 2011 |url=http://www.freedomflotilla.eu/en/information/3-freedomflotilla-announcements/129-press-release-from-istanbul |title=Press Release from Istanbul |publisher=Freedomflotilla.eu |accessdate=1 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110625001123/http://freedomflotilla.eu/en/information/3-freedomflotilla-announcements/129-press-release-from-istanbul |archivedate=25 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Initially, 10 ships, with 1,000 activists<ref name="AJN_24Jun2011a"/> were set to sail for Gaza, but by 28 June 2011, the [[List of participants of Freedom Flotilla II|number of expected participants]] had decreased to fewer than 300, plus a few dozen journalists, and by 7 July all but a few dozen activists had returned home.<ref name="Katz-2010"/><ref name="Magnezi-28-June-2011">{{cite news |last=Magnezi |first=Aviel |date=28 June 2011 |title=Fewer than 300 join flotilla |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4088464,00.html |work=Ynetnews |location=Tel Aviv |accessdate=30 June 2011}}</ref>
The flotilla was publicly opposed by the United States, France, the United Kingdom, Turkey, Canada, the [[Middle East Quartet]] (consisting of the [[European Union]], Russia, the United Nations, and the United States), and [[United Nations Secretary General]] [[Ban Ki-moon]]. It was publicly supported by [[Hamas]].<ref name="cbc.ca">{{cite news |date=2 July 2011 |title=Gaza-bound activists vow to complete trek |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/story/2011/07/03/gaza-flotilla.html |work=CBC World News |accessdate=2 July 2011}}</ref>
Activists on two ships, one in Greece and one in Turkey, found similar damage to their propeller shafts, and claimed that the ships had been sabotaged by Israel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/israel-also-sabotaged-irish-ship-say-gaza-flotilla-organizers-1.370434 |title=Israel also sabotaged Irish ship, say Gaza flotilla organizers |work=Haaretz |location=Israel|accessdate=30 June 2011}}</ref> It was reported that the investigation by Turkish authorities on one of the ships determined that there may have been no sabotage at all, and that any damage happened before the boat arrived in Turkey, but these media reports appeared prior to the formal investigation beginning and the Turkish coastguard enquiry has yet to announce its findings. The media reports were disputed by Irish Ship to Gaza, the owner of the vessel.<ref name="apgreece"/><ref name="greece_blocks_boat"/><ref>{{cite web |date=4 July 2011 |title=Sabotage of MV Saoirse |url=http://irishshiptogaza.org/?p=746 |work=Blog archive |publisher=Irish Ship to Gaza |accessdate=5 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707062019/http://irishshiptogaza.org/?p=746 |archivedate=7 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Greece forbade the vessels from leaving its ports, citing safety concerns,<ref name="greek"/> but offered to instead send any humanitarian aid to Gaza in its own vessels, under United Nations supervision. Greece's offer was supported by Israel, the Palestinian Authority, and the United Nations, but rejected by the flotilla activists.<ref name="voareject"/><ref name="bill"/> Subsequently, two flotilla ships, the ''Audacity of Hope'' and ''Tahrir'', disobeyed Greece's orders. They were intercepted by the Greek coast guard, brought back to shore, and a few activists were arrested. Activists responded by occupying the Spanish embassy in Athens.<ref name="sunk"/>
Only the French ship ''Dignité Al Karama'' managed to approach Gaza. They advised the Greek authorities that their destination was the Egyptian port of [[Alexandria]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://alethonews.wordpress.com/2011/07/18/dignite-al-karama-sailing-to-gaza/ |title=Dignité-Al Karama sailing to Gaza |work=Aletho News |date=18 July 2011 |accessdate=22 August 2011}}</ref> and then turned toward Gaza.<ref name="AlJazeera-2011-07-18"/> On 19 July, the ship was intercepted and boarded without incident by Israeli commandos and escorted to the Israeli port of [[Ashdod]].<ref name="BBC-2011-07-19"/>
==Background== [[Image:Gazaseablocade.png|thumb|250px|Gaza Strip naval blockade area, as published by Israel's Ministry of Transport]] After the 2007, [[Fatah-Hamas conflict]], Israel and Egypt closed off their respective borders with Gaza, preventing most goods and nearly all people from going in and out.<ref name="NYT_16June2011a"/>
At the end of May 2010 a flotilla of six ships left from Turkey towards the Gaza Strip. The main purpose of the flotilla, according to its organizers, was to bring humanitarian supplies to the Gaza Strip. On 31 May 2010 the [[Gaza flotilla raid|Israeli navy raided the ships]] some 40 kilometres away from Gaza shores. During the takeover, a violent confrontation occurred in which nine activists were killed on one of the ships and several Israeli soldiers were injured as well as dozens of passengers from several ships. At the end of the operation the ships were seized by the Israeli navy and taken to the port of Ashdod.
Following the 2010 Gaza flotilla raid, international outrage contributed to a shift in Israeli policy. Both Israel and Egypt eased their blockade, letting in more goods over land.<ref name="NYT_16June2011a"/> In June 2010 Egypt decided to open the land crossings between Egypt and the Gaza Strip in order to transfer a minimal amount of supplies.
After the events of the 2011 flotilla raid, organizations from several countries declared their intention to send more ships to break the blockade on Gaza. As a result, the Israeli government announced that the any ships attempting to break the blockade of the Gaza Strip would be arrested.
Opinions on the [[Legal assessments of the Gaza flotilla raid#Legality of blockade|legality]] of Israel's blockade of the Gaza strip, as well as on the use of force in international waters to maintain the blockade, are divided.<ref name="washingtonpost1">{{cite news |last=Lynch |first=Colum |date=1 June 2010 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/06/01/AR2010060102934.html?hpid=topnews |title=Israel's flotilla raid revives questions of international law |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Hirsch |first=Afua |date=1 June 2010 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/law/afua-hirsch-law-blog/2010/jun/01/gaza-freedom-flotilla-international-law |title=Was the Gaza Flotilla Raid Illegal? |work=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref>
On 3 July 2011, the Greek government offered to bring humanitarian aid to Gaza themselves, but Greece's offer was turned down by the activists.<ref>{{cite news |last=Katz |first=Yaakov |date=4 July 2011 |title=Activists reject Greek offer to send flotilla aid |url=http://www.jpost.com/International/Article.aspx?id=227783 |work=Jerusalem Post |accessdate=7 July 2011}}</ref>
==Structure==
===Name=== The flotilla was named in memory of [[Vittorio Arrigoni]], an Italian reporter and activist whose killing by suspected members of a Palestinian [[Salafist jihadism|Salafist]] group in Gaza in April 2011 "left the Palestinian activist community stunned." His favourite expression was "Stay Human".<ref>{{Cite news|last=Schwartz |first=Susan |date=2 June 2011 |title=The Stay Human Flotilla to Gaza |url=http://muslimmedianetwork.com/mmn/?p=8577 |location=Farmington, MI |work=Muslim Observer |accessdate=26 June 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111002214756/http://muslimmedianetwork.com/mmn/?p=8577 |deadurl=no |archivedate=2 October 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref>
===Ships=== Originally it was thought that the [[MV Mavi Marmara|MV ''Mavi Marmara'']] would lead the flotilla, but in mid-June, IHH announced that the ship would be unable to sail due to technical issues.<ref name="NYT_17June2011a">{{cite news |last=Arsu |first=Sebnem |date=17 June 2011 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/18/world/europe/18briefs-Turkey.html |title=Turkey: Aid Ship Won't Join Flotilla |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=30 June 2011}}</ref> As of 10 July 2011, the following ships had planned on sailing to reach Gaza:<ref name="Hass-2011"/>
